title: Pre-generation of 2FA secret/backup codes seems like an unnecessary risk

activities.message: (I'll admit that I could be completely wrong here and misinterpreting what I'm observing.  It's difficult to test as I only have one account that can actually enable 2FA and have to be somewhat careful that I don't accidentally lock myself out of my account … the main thing is that it just seemed strange that the 2FA stuff was being generated in advance)
activities.markdown_message: (I'll admit that I could be completely wrong here and misinterpreting what I'm observing. It's difficult to test as I only have one account that can actually enable 2FA and have to be somewhat careful that I don't accidentally lock myself out of my account … the main thing is that it just seemed strange that the 2FA stuff was being generated in advance)

activities.message:
Hello @danlec,

Thanks for your report! I'll start a discussion about the (premature) generation of the 2FA values.
activities.markdown_message:
Hello @danlec,

Thanks for your report! I'll start a discussion about the (premature) generation of the 2FA values.

activities.message: The interesting question to me is "Does the fact that HackerOne requires an active session and knowledge of the user's login credentials (password and possibly TOTP code) to alter the 2FA settings square with the fact that you seemingly only need an active session to know what the 2FA settings will be?"
activities.markdown_message: The interesting question to me is "Does the fact that HackerOne requires an active session and knowledge of the user's login credentials (password and possibly TOTP code) to alter the 2FA settings square with the fact that you seemingly only need an active session to know what the 2FA settings will be?"

activities.message: The backup codes are generated (but *not* saved) every time you load the 2FA page. As in, reload the page, and you will get a different set of backup codes (until you actually enter your password and your TOTP code). With that in mind, is this really a concern in itself?
activities.markdown_message: The backup codes are generated (but not saved) every time you load the 2FA page. As in, reload the page, and you will get a different set of backup codes (until you actually enter your password and your TOTP code). With that in mind, is this really a concern in itself?

activities.message:
@reed Interesting.  In my experimentation I wasn't (and still don't appear to be) getting a different set of backup codes on a reload.  On refresh I observe the various `authenticity_token`s changing, but the set of potential backup codes remains the same. 

For example, from the console:

```
$.get('https://hackerone.com/settings/authentication/edit').then(function(html){ console.log($(html).find('#regenerate-backup-codes-authentication-modal li:first').text()) })
37d4 f16d ad0e a6b2
$.get('https://hackerone.com/settings/authentication/edit').then(function(html){ console.log($(html).find('#regenerate-backup-codes-authentication-modal li:first').text()) })
37d4 f16d ad0e a6b2
$.get('https://hackerone.com/settings/authentication/edit').then(function(html){ console.log($(html).find('#regenerate-backup-codes-authentication-modal li:first').text()) })
37d4 f16d ad0e a6b2
```

(and then if I open another window, and go to the Authentication section and click "Regenerate", that is the first backup code listed and would presumably be a valid code were I to confirm the regeneration)

I may be misinterpreting this; I would agree that if the backup codes are in fact changing on every load then this is definitely not a concern.
activities.markdown_message:
@reed Interesting. In my experimentation I wasn't (and still don't appear to be) getting a different set of backup codes on a reload. On refresh I observe the various authenticity_tokens changing, but the set of potential backup codes remains the same.

For example, from the console:

$.get('https://hackerone.com/settings/authentication/edit').then(function(html){ console.log($(html).find('#regenerate-backup-codes-authentication-modal li:first').text()) })
37d4 f16d ad0e a6b2
$.get('https://hackerone.com/settings/authentication/edit').then(function(html){ console.log($(html).find('#regenerate-backup-codes-authentication-modal li:first').text()) })
37d4 f16d ad0e a6b2
$.get('https://hackerone.com/settings/authentication/edit').then(function(html){ console.log($(html).find('#regenerate-backup-codes-authentication-modal li:first').text()) })
37d4 f16d ad0e a6b2

(and then if I open another window, and go to the Authentication section and click "Regenerate", that is the first backup code listed and would presumably be a valid code were I to confirm the regeneration)

I may be misinterpreting this; I would agree that if the backup codes are in fact changing on every load then this is definitely not a concern.

activities.message:
I believe we generate a new pair and keep those ready in your session until you confirm these are the codes you want (by entering your password and a working 2FA code). 

I'd like to add to @reed's comment that as soon as you confirm the backup codes, we do not know the plaintext anymore. We store hashed versions of each backup codes to ensure only you have the plaintext and we're just able to verify you do.
activities.markdown_message:
I believe we generate a new pair and keep those ready in your session until you confirm these are the codes you want (by entering your password and a working 2FA code).

I'd like to add to @reed's comment that as soon as you confirm the backup codes, we do not know the plaintext anymore. We store hashed versions of each backup codes to ensure only you have the plaintext and we're just able to verify you do.

activities.message: Ugh, you're right. In my earlier testing before this went live, I definitely thought I tested that case, but seems like it's not doing the right thing. We definitely shouldn't do that. :(
activities.markdown_message: Ugh, you're right. In my earlier testing before this went live, I definitely thought I tested that case, but seems like it's not doing the right thing. We definitely shouldn't do that. :(

activities.message:
@reed Oh good, I glad I'm not just crazy :D

The fact that the codes weren't being regenerated every time felt wrong (and was the thing I was trying to allude to with the "possibly closes and re-opens the window" and "could be mitigated by not generating the 2FA values until the user is trying to enable 2FA" in my initial description)
activities.markdown_message:
@reed Oh good, I glad I'm not just crazy :D

The fact that the codes weren't being regenerated every time felt wrong (and was the thing I was trying to allude to with the "possibly closes and re-opens the window" and "could be mitigated by not generating the 2FA values until the user is trying to enable 2FA" in my initial description)

activities.message:
Hi @danlec 

We deployed a fix for this issue. Can you confirm this has been fixed now?
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @danlec

We deployed a fix for this issue. Can you confirm this has been fixed now?

activities.message: I can confirm that https://hackerone.com/settings/authentication/edit now contains new backup codes (and in cases where 2FA isn't set up, a new TOTP secret) every time it's loaded.  Now if an attacker were able to get a potential set of codes it wouldn't matter, because that wouldn't be the set used when the victim went to confirm regeneration of the codes.
activities.markdown_message: I can confirm that https://hackerone.com/settings/authentication/edit now contains new backup codes (and in cases where 2FA isn't set up, a new TOTP secret) every time it's loaded. Now if an attacker were able to get a potential set of codes it wouldn't matter, because that wouldn't be the set used when the victim went to confirm regeneration of the codes.

activities.message:
As always, thanks for the awesome report.

Please do keep poking away and find other issues. ;) -- Happy hacking!
activities.markdown_message:
As always, thanks for the awesome report.

Please do keep poking away and find other issues. ;) -- Happy hacking!

vulnerability_information_html:
If you manage to get a malicious script running in HackerOne, requesting https://hackerone.com/settings/authentication/edit and parsing out the two factor authentication form will yield either…

  • the 2FA secret key and backup codes that will be used if 2FA is enabled for the first time this session
  • the backup codes that will be used if 2FA is already being used and the codes are regenerated during this session

While activating 2FA or confirming backup codes regeneration requires knowledge of the user's password/TOTP code, reading the values out from the DOM does not (again, provided that you've compromised the user's session and are running script in their domain)

A theoretical attack might play out like this:

  • A victim clicks a link or something in HackerOne which triggers XSS (which seems unlikely, but …)
  • The XSS makes a request to https://hackerone.com/settings/authentication/edit to obtain the victim's potential 2FA secret and backup codes. Possibly the attacker is able to abuse a password manager's behavior to obtain the victim's username/password at this point.
  • Because of the strange behavior that occurred when they clicked the link, the victim possibly closes and re-opens the window (in an attempt to stop whatever the script is doing) and then enables 2FA on their account
  • The attacker would now know the 2FA secret and backup codes that are currently being used for the victim's account

While achieving this attack seems rather unlikely, it seems that it could be mitigated by not generating the 2FA values until the user is trying to enable 2FA or generate their codes and has provided their password (and then generating new codes each time, regardless of whether the process was cancelled previously)

(Also, I was somewhat surprised to see that the https://hackerone.com/settings/authentication/edit form contained a 2FA secret/backup codes for users that aren't allowed to set up two factor authentication.)
vulnerability_information:
If you manage to get a malicious script running in HackerOne, requesting `https://hackerone.com/settings/authentication/edit` and parsing out the two factor authentication form will yield either… 

- the 2FA secret key and backup codes that *will* be used if 2FA is enabled for the first time this session
- the backup codes that *will* be used if 2FA is already being used and the codes are regenerated during this session

While *activating* 2FA or *confirming* backup codes regeneration requires knowledge of the user's password/TOTP code, reading the values out from the DOM does not (again, provided that you've compromised the user's session and are running script in their domain)

A theoretical attack might play out like this:

- A victim clicks a link or something in HackerOne which triggers XSS (which seems unlikely, but …)
- The XSS makes a request to `https://hackerone.com/settings/authentication/edit` to obtain the victim's potential 2FA secret and backup codes.  Possibly the attacker is able to abuse a password manager's behavior to obtain the victim's username/password at this point.
- Because of the strange behavior that occurred when they clicked the link, the victim possibly closes and re-opens the window (in an attempt to stop whatever the script is doing) and then enables 2FA on their account
- The attacker would now know the 2FA secret and backup codes that are currently being used for the victim's account

While achieving this attack seems rather unlikely, it seems that it could be mitigated by not generating the 2FA values until the user is trying to enable 2FA or generate their codes and has provided their password (and then generating new codes each time, regardless of whether the process was cancelled previously)

(Also, I was somewhat surprised to see that the `https://hackerone.com/settings/authentication/edit` form contained a 2FA secret/backup codes for users that aren't allowed to set up two factor authentication.)

profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.
profile.name: HackerOne
